title: Good sex? Building evidence based practice in sexual health services for young people.
abstractText:
This is a one year knowledge exchange project involving a collaboration between the University of Sussex and the young people’s sexual health charity Brook. The aim of the project is to explore new and creative ways of using research to inform evidence based practice in youth sexual health service delivery. The focus of the project will be on developing ‘sex-positive’ approaches to young people’s sexual health and on creating tools for practitioners to use to engage young people in work around ‘good sex’ and sexual pleasure.

 

The project will involve a team of researchers, practitioners, young people, a film-maker and a theatre director/writer who will use original research on young people’s sexual relationships and cultures to produce the following outputs:

  • Three short films targeting;
  1. young people
  2. sexual health practitioners/educators
  3. general public

 

 

 

 

 

 

  • A training programme and resources for sexual health practitioners on engaging young people in work around sexual pleasure
  • An module on pleasure to be included in Brook’s online induction programme
  • A literature review of evidence for ‘sex-positive’ approaches to education and service development
  • A research blog documenting the knowledge exchange methods used: goodsexproject.wordpress.com
impactText: The aim of the project was to develop flexible materials and resources that communicate the findings from previous research to non-academic communities. In particular this project has targeted youth and sexual health practitioner communities. This has been achieved through setting up a 2 day workshop for young people, a 10 week workshop for young people, 1 pilot training day and 2 training days for practitioners. It has also been achieved through ongoing informal interaction and collaboration be Education,Healthcare Cultural,Societal,Policy & public services
findingsText:
The 'good sex' project set out to apply to findings from a co-funded doctoral research on young people's sexual cultures project to Brook's work in three areas: public awareness; direct work with young people; skills development for the sexual health workforce. This was to be achieved through creating flexible resources that could be used in in organisational development, training and campaigning.
